questions.solution:
Metabolic Pathways falls in three different category.

  • Anabolic Pathway - Endothermic pathway require reducing equivalents or ATP
    1. Involved in the synthesis of larger and more complex compounds from smaller precursors:
      • The synthesis of protein from amino acid.
      • The synthesis of triacylglycerol and glycogen from carbohydrates - Gluconeogenesis,
  • Catabolic Pathway - endothermic, produced reducing equivalent & involve in breakdown of larger molecules like oxidative reactions - E.g. Glycogenolysis
  • Amphibolic Pathway: Participate in Anabolic & Catabolic Functions E.g Citric Acid Cycle.
    • In TCA cycle, Acetyl Co A is converted to Reducing Equivalent and CO2 which makes it Catabolic Pathway.
    • Similarly, in same TCA cycle is source of various other Biosynthetic Precursor like Citrate - for Sterol, Fatty acid, Alpha ketoglutarate for Glutamate, Succinyl CoA for Porphyrin, oxaloacetate for Aspartate and Glucose etc.
    • Only pathway is pure catabolic Pathway is Electron Transport Chain.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated biochemistry Textbook, 32nd Edition, chapter 14, page number. 133

Trehalose is disaccharide containing Glucose & Glucose with alpha 1-1 Glycosidic Linkages.

  • If Disaccharide containing Alpha 1-4 Glycosidic Linkages and Glucose & Glucose is forms Maltose.
  • Similarly, Isomaltose is made up of Glucose & Glucose but having Alpha 1-6 Glycosidic Linkage.
  • Lactose contains Glucose & Galactose having Beta 1-4 Glycosidic Linkage.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry Textbook, 32nd Edition, Chapter 15, Page number:153

questions.text: Derivatives of Digitalis will act by inhibiting Na K ATPase pump used in Cardiac Patient. Aglycone contain of this Cardiac Glycoside is ?
questions.solution:
Glycosides are formed by condensation between the hydroxy group of the anomeric carbon of a monosaccharide and a second compound that may be another monosaccharide (Glycone) or nonsaccharide group (Aglycone).

Digitalis is cardiac Glycosides which acts on Na K ATPase Pump and inhibit its action. Cardiac Glycoside contains sterol as Aglycone group. Other examples which contains sterol as Aglycone includes Bile Acid, Adrenocortic Hormone, Sex Hormone.

Other Aglycone compounds are Methanol, Phenol, Glycerol, Base such as adenine.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry Textbook 32nd Edition, Chapter 15, Page number:150, Chapter 21, Page number: 212, Chapter 40, Page number. 480

questions.text: ATP formation during Glycolysis of One Mole of Glucose is _______ out of Which _______ is used during Process
questions.solution: Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry - 32nd Edition Chapter: 17 Page number:164

questions.text: In Fluoride Blood collection tube, Enzyme of Glycolytic Pathway is inhibited & this reaction also requires presence of ________ ion?
questions.solution:
• Fluoride will inhibit Enolase which is enzyme of Glycolytic Pathway.
  • In Glycolysis, Conversion of 2 Phosphoglycerate to Phosphoenolpyruvate requires Enolase enzyme. If this reactions continues, it will leads to complete breakdown of Glucose which will affect the Measurement of Blood Glucose level in received Sample.
  • So during Blood Glucose Estimation, Fluoride Blood Collection tube is used for Estimation of Plasma Glucose from Blood Sample.
  • Activity of Enolase is also dependent on presence of Mg++ and Mn+ ions.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Textbook of Biochemistry 32nd Edition, Chapter: 17 Page number:167

questions.text: 12 year old boy is having muscle cramps and weakness particularly after exercise. He had mild icteric and pallor. Urine shows dark color possibility of hemolysis. Genetic study shows mutation in ALODA gene. Identify the Disease.
questions.solution:
Aldolase A deficiency is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder that affects the glycolytic pathway.

Aldolase A, an enzyme primarily expressed in muscle and red blood cells, plays a vital role in breaking down glucose for energy production.

Deficiency in Aldolase A leads to impaired glycolysis, causing hemolytic anemia and myopathy. This case report discusses a patient presenting with symptoms consistent with Aldolase A deficiency.

The hallmark of the disease includes recurrent episodes of muscle weakness, hemolysis, and exercise intolerance. Diagnosis is confirmed through enzyme activity assays and genetic testing. There is no specific treatment for Aldolase A deficiency, and management focuses on preventing hemolysis and managing anemia.

Option A) Phenylalanine is first convert to tyrosine. subsequent reactions are those of tyrosine Hyperphenylalaninemias arise from defects in phenylalanine Hydroxylase enzyme leads to Phenylketonuria.

Option B) Hemoglobinuria leads to presence of Hb in Urine. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is an acquired mild anemia characterized by the presence of hemoglobin in urine due to hemolysis of red cells, particularly during sleep, reflecting a slight drop in plasma pH during sleep, which increases susceptibility to lysis by the complement system.

Option D) Deficiency of Homogentisate Oxidase leads to Alkaptonuria. The urine darkens on exposure to air due to oxidation of excreted homogentisate. Late in the disease, there is arthritis and connective tissue pigmentation due to oxidation of homogentisate to benzoquinone acetate, which polymerizes and binds to connective tissue.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition, Chapter 17, Page number: 174

questions.text: A 45 years old male patient suffering from Cirrhosis of Liver. Impairment of Carbohydrate Metabolism can be identify by doing
questions.solution:
The Galactose Tolerance Test is used for Estimation of Liver Functions.

In liver Dysfunction as mentioned in above patient - Cirrhosis of Liver, Galactose which is not metabolized by liver and excreted in urine. Increase amount of galactose in urine after intravenous injection of Galactose in Galactose Tolerance test is suggestive of Liver Dysfunction.

Option A) Glucose Tolerance test is to detect body's intolerance to Glucose load specifically done to detect presence of diabetes Mellitus.

Option C) Fasting Blood Sugar is also done as a part of Diagnostic criteria for detection of Diabetes Mellitus.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated textbook of Biochemistry 32nd Edition Chapter 20 Page number:198

questions.text: Characteristic of Hunter's Syndrome are all except
questions.solution:
• Hunter's Syndrome is X linked lysosomal Storage Clinical Presentation includes Mental Retardation, Coarse Facials Features, Dysostosis Multiplex and deficiency of Iduronate 2 Sulphatase.
  • All mucopolysaccharidoses are autosomal recessive except Hunter's disease(x-linked recessive)

Reference: Harper's Illustrate Biochemistry, 32nd edition, Chapter 50, Page number: 611

questions.text: Aspirin induced Asthma is due to
questions.solution:
• Aspirin inhibits Cyclooxygenase pathway. This will leads to decreased production of PGD2, PGF2, PGI2, TXA2. Due to this, Arachidonic Acid is diverted towards Lipoxygenase Pathway leading to formation of This will lead to Aspirin Induced Asthma.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition chapter 23 page number 237

questions.text: In Fatty Acid Oxidation, Enzyme used for penetration of Acyl Carnitine to inner membrane is
questions.solution:
• Carnitine AcylCarnitine Translocase is present in inner Mitochondrial Membrane which helps AcylCarnitine to Penetrate the inner membrane.
  • The Other enzymes used during Fatty Acid Oxidation process, like CPT-1 is present in Outer Mitochondrial Membrane and it transfers long chain acyl group from CoA to carnitine forming Acylcarnitine.

CPT-II is present in Inner Mitochondrial Membrane, along with CPT-I it oxidizes long chain fatty acids in the Mitochondria.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition, Chapter 22, Page number: 217

questions.text: In uncontrolled Diabetes Mellitus, Metabolic Alteration takes place leading to
questions.solution:
• A decreased insulin-to-glucagon ratio leads to a decrease in fatty acid synthesis and an increase in adipose triacylglycerol degradation, leading to fatty acid release into the circulation.
  • The liver takes up the fatty acids, and within the mitochondria, fatty acids undergo beta -oxidation. As acetyl CoA accumulates, the ketone bodies, acetoacetate and beta-hydroxybutyrate, are formed and are released into the circulation.
  • These ketone bodies are used to fuel the heart, brain, and muscle. Nonenzymatic decarboxylation of acetoacetate forms acetone, which can be smelled by some providers on the breath of patients in diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • Because triglycerides are degraded under these conditions, there is not an increase in triglyceride storage. Pancreatitis does not result from an inability to produce insulin

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition Chapter: 22 Page Number 157.

choices.text: In the fasting state adipose tissue synthesizes glucose from the glycerol release by the break down of triacylglycerol.
In the fasting state adipose tissue synthesizes ketone bodies.
In the fasting state the main fuel for red blood cells is fatty acids released from adipose tissue.
Plasma glucose is maintained in starvation and prolongs fasting by gluconeogenesis in the liver from the amino acids released by the breakdown of muscle protein.

questions.text: Changes occurred during Fed State & Fasting state is best explained by
questions.solution:
Plasma glucose is maintained in starvation and prolonged fasting by gluconeogenesis in the liver from the amino acids released by the breakdown of muscle protein.

a. Glycogenolysis is stimulated as blood glucose falls to the fasting level after a meal. It is the main source of blood glucose for the next 8 to 12 hours.

b. Gluconeogenesis is stimulated within a few hours (upto 4 hours) after a meal and supplies an increasingly larger share of blood glucose as the fasting state persists.

c. By 16 hours of fasting, gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis are about equal as sources of blood glucose.

d. As liver glycogen stores become depleted, gluconeogenesis predominates.

e. By about 30 hours of fasting, liver glycogen is depleted, and thereafter, gluconeogenesis is the only source of blood glucose.

Option A) In the fasting state, adipose tissue synthesizes glucose from the glycerol released by the breakdown of triacylglycerols - the liver uses this glycerol for gluconeogenesis, not the adipose tissue itself.

Option B) In the fasting state, adipose tissue not synthesizes ketone bodies - Ketone bodies are synthesized in the liver from fatty acids, not in adipose tissue.

Option C) In the fasting state, the main fuel for red blood cells is not fatty acids released from adipose tissue - Red blood cells lack mitochondria and rely solely on glucose for energy, even in fasting states.

Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 28, Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition, Chapter 14, page number: 142.

questions.text: In classification of Lipids, Non Phophorylated Lipids includes
questions.solution:
Non Phosphorylated Lipids includes

  1. Glycerosphingolipids - Cerebrosides, Globosides and Gangliosides
  2. Sulphated Cerebrosides

Cephalin & Sphingomyelin is Compound lipid - Phospholipid. But Cephalin is nitrogen glycerophosphatides like lecithin while Sphingomyelin is Phosphosphingosides.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition Chapter 20 page number: 288

choices.text: ATP and NAD levels are increased
Conversion of Acetyl Co Enzyme A to Acetoacetate increased
Decreased Ability to covert acetyl Coenzyme A to Glucose
Decreased Acetyl Co Enzyme A Production

questions.text: In Medium Chain Fatty Acyl Coenzyme A Dehydrogenase Deficiency, Fasting Hypoglycemia is due to?
questions.solution:
In Medium Chain Fatty Acyl Coenzyme A Dehydrogenase Deficiency, there is impaired Oxidation of Fatty acid <12 carbon results in decreased production of acetyl coenzyme A.

Acetyl Co Enzyme A is allosteric Regulator of Pyruvate Carboxylase. Role of Pyruvate Carboxylase is in Gluconeogenic Pathway, So impaired function of Pyruvate Carboxylase leading to decreased production of Glucose leading to hypoglycemia.

Acetyl Co Enzyme A is never used for production of Glucose. In MCAD deficiency, Ketogenesis is decreased due to less availability of Substrate. So level of Acetoacetate is not increased.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 21 Page Number. 307-310
Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry SA Edition, Chapter 23, Page number:357
